author: Brendan O'Brien
title: Three Christian missionaries from Oklahoma-based group killed in Haiti | News | gazette.com
text: (Reuters) - Three Christian missionaries from Missions in Haiti were shot and killed in an ambush by a gang in Haiti, the Oklahoma-based group said on Friday. The missionaries were taking shelter in a house when gang members began shooting at the residence at about 9 p.m. CDT (0200 GMT) Thursday, the group said in two Facebook posts. Months of gang violence in Haiti have forced the government into retreat, and U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken has warned the country is close to becoming a failed state. Haiti’s main international airport in Port-au-Prince reopened this week, nearly three months after it shut due to deadly gang-related violence. But gangs still control much of the capital and Haiti's main seaport remains closed. "Unfortunately, this serves as a reminder that the security situation in Haiti cannot wait – too many innocent lives are being lost," State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said in a statement. Missouri State Representative Ben Baker said his daughter Natalie Lloyd and son-in-law Davy Lloyd were killed while working as full-time missionaries. Davy Lloyd was the son of the organization's founders, David and Alicia Lloyd, who started it in 2000. The identity of the third person killed has not been released. "My heart is broken in a thousand pieces. I’ve never felt this kind of pain," Baker said on Facebook. Missions in Haiti said the couple was leaving a church when they were ambushed by three trucks full of gang members. They took Davy Lloyd to a house, tied him up and beat him, before taking the group's trucks and some items and left, it said. "Another gang came after to see what was going on and if they could help, so they say," the organization said. "No one understood what they were doing, not sure what took place but one was shot and killed and now this gang went into full attack mode." The couple and another individual identified as Jude called a leader of the organization on a satellite phone and said that their lives were in danger. (Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Chicago; Additional reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt and Jasper Ward in Washington; Editing by Doina Chiacu and Rod Nickel)

author: BVM Sportsdesk
title: Ike and Nembhard Named NABC All-District
text:
Ike and Nembhard Named NABC All-District
Gonzaga's Graham Ike and Ryan Nembhard have been named to the NABC First Team All-Pacific District, with Ike earning this honor for the second consecutive year. The selection, determined by NABC-member coaches across NCAA Division I, also follows their recent recognition as First Team All-West Coast Conference. A new alignment model for the NABC Division I districts places schools by state rather than conference, enhancing geographic representation. Ike leads the conference with a scoring average of 17.1 points per game and boasts the highest shooting percentage at 59.9%, while Nembhard set a national record with 325 assists this season.
- Graham Ike averages 17.1 points per game, ranking fourth in the conference.
- Ryan Nembhard's 325 assists make him the national leader this season.
- The NABC introduced a new Division I district structure this season, grouping teams by state.
- Both players are recognized for their consistent performance, earning All-WCC honors for the second year.
As the postseason approaches, Ike and Nembhard will aim to leverage their accolades and strong performances in the NCAA Tournament, with hopes of leading Gonzaga deep into the tournament.
Bottom LineGonzaga's standout performances from Ike and Nembhard underscore the team's strength as they head into the postseason, reflecting individual excellence and a promising shot at success in the NCAA Tournament.
Read more at Gonzaga University Athletics

author: Wake Up World
title: Explore the Secrets of Working with Higher-Frequency Beings
text:
What if your spirit guides held the key to unlocking a deeper understanding of your gifts and spiritual path? Imagine opening more to your innate psychic abilities and connecting better to your guides — tapping into their wellspring of wisdom, guidance, and support.
Explore 7 New Ways to Collaborate with Your Spirit Guides Join us for an enlightening event where psychic medium Sheila Vijeyarasa shares seven new ways to work with your spirit guides and connect with other higher-frequency beings to receive guidance and healing.
Register for free: Join us for this online event
Sheila will also guide us in a channeling meditation to receive a message from a guide on our top priority, the healing that needs to happen, and how they will work with us as we acknowledge and advance our psychic gifts.
Discover the Power of Working with Spirit Guides Gain Confidence and Accelerate Psychic Abilities Learn seven ways to work with your spirit guides to gain confidence in your spiritual path, accelerate your psychic abilities, and live in greater flow. Dispelling old myths about guides will help dissolve limiting beliefs and assumptions that separate you from your guides, stepping into a multidimensional reality that nurtures your physical and spiritual self.
Reclaim Your Psychic and Spiritual Self-Esteem Begin reclaiming your psychic and spiritual self-esteem and trust in being a channel. Shift out of lower frequencies and increase your ability to attract new guides. Discover how you can begin working with various spirit guides in your daily life to gain more flow, support, and empowerment.
Deepen Your Trust with Your Spirit Team Deepen your trust with your spirit team to dispel doubt and gain confidence in your psychic abilities, accelerating your progression on the spiritual path. Sheila’s practical approach for connecting with the nonphysical and beyond — whether it’s loved ones who have crossed over, otherworldly beings, ancestors, or spirit guides — is built on decades of study and application at renowned institutions like Esalen, the Arthur Findlay College in England, and the Omega Institute with world-renowned psychic medium James Van Praagh.
Embrace Your Psychic Self-Esteem Sheila teaches that our confidence in our abilities and capacity to handle life with ease and agency is directly connected to our psychic self-esteem. Trusting our intuition, greater purpose, and connection to a higher power—and to loving beings in other realms who have a higher vantage point than we do— is crucial for our spiritual journey .
What You’ll Learn and Experience:
Seven ways to work with your spirit guides to gain confidence in your spiritual path How to accelerate your psychic abilities and live in greater flow Dispel old myths about guides to dissolve limiting beliefs Step into a multidimensional reality that nurtures your physical and spiritual self Reclaim your psychic and spiritual self-esteem and trust in being a channel Increase your ability to attract new guides Gain more flow, support, and empowerment by working with an array of spirit guides in your daily life Deepen your trust in your spirit team to dispel doubt and gain confidence in your psychic abilities Practical techniques for connecting with loved ones who have crossed over, otherworldly beings, ancestors, or spirit guides We hope you’ll join us for this hour-long free online event. Don’t miss this opportunity to enhance your flexibility, resilience, and mental sharpness.
RSVP for free: Register here

author: Sgcarmart
title: HMGICS launches new Smart Food Lab workshop for kids
text:
HMGICS launches new Smart Food Lab workshop for kids
Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Centre Singapore (HMGICS) has announced the launch of its Smart Food Lab, a new sensory workshop that is an add-on to its existing complimentary Discovery Tour.
The Smart Food Lab workshop invites children aged three to six to embark on a hands-on, sensory-led exploration of food grown in modern, technology-assisted environments, as well as helping children to understand where their food comes from.
Starting from 21 June 2025, in 60-minute sessions held every Saturday and Sunday from 10:00am to 11:00am and 04:00pm to 05:00pm, children and their accompanying parent or guardian will take part in a series of guided activities exploring food through sight, sound, smell, touch, and taste.
Participants will explore the differences between traditionally grown produce and crops cultivated in HMGICS's high-tech Smart Farm, distinguish different foods by the sounds they make, identify both familiar and new scents, and examine the textures of select crops. The workshop concludes with a fun, interactive Ssam (wrap) making activity using fresh produce from the Smart Farm.
Each session can accommodate up to eight children, who must each be accompanied by a parent or guardian throughout. This program is chargeable at $15 per child, with proceeds from these workshops donated to the President's Challenge.
Interested families are encouraged to sign up for the Smart Food Lab workshop via this link. Bookings are encouraged as spaces are limited.
Looking ahead, the public can also look forward to other exciting initiatives, including a kids' coding workshop featuring a miniature version of SPOT, the four-legged robot developed by Boston Dynamics that HMGICS uses for inspecting assembly quality.

author: @echodelargoat
title: Côtes-d'Armor : cette petite commune veut devenir un havre de paix pour les hirondelles | L'Écho de l'Argoat
text:
Voir mon actu Suivre L'Écho de l'Argoat « Devenir un havre de paix pour les hirondelles et un espace de cohabitation harmonieuse avec l’homme… »
C’est l’ambition que se donne la commune de Bulat-Pestivien , entre Guingamp et Callac ( Côtes-d’Armor ), au travers de ce programme pour la protection des hirondelles , mené en partenariat avec la Ligue de protection des oiseaux ( LPO ).
Des espèces menacées « Il consiste à fournir à l’équipe municipale ainsi qu’aux citoyens du territoire des outils leur permettant de changer de regard sur ces espèces menacées, de mobiliser les énergies locales et d’engager des actions simples pour que chaque année, les hirondelles reviennent toujours plus nombreuses », expose Viviane Troadec, de la LPO Bretagne.
Le déclin alarmant des populations d’hirondelles de fenêtre et d’hirondelles rustiques leur vaut désormais d’être inscrites sur la liste rouge de l’union internationale pour la conservation de la nature, avec le statut quasi menacé. Le constat est tout aussi préoccupant pour le martinet noir, espèce qui niche également dans les milieux bâtis et urbanisés.
À lire aussi
7 sorties nature à découvrir cet été en famille entre Guingamp et Paimpol La destruction des nids Parmi les causes de régression, la destruction des nids est un facteur important, alors que toutes les espèces d’hirondelles et martinets sont protégées par la loi. « Il est interdit de porter atteinte aux individus et à leurs couvées, mais aussi de détruire leurs nids, même hors période de reproduction ».
Vidéos : en ce moment sur Actu « La commune de Bulat-Pestivien se sent concernée et veut agir pour la protection de ces espèces annonciatrices du printemps », affirme Olivier Charles , maire de la commune.
« À l’école, depuis plusieurs années, un regard sensible est porté aux hirondelles avec la nomination de la princesse et du prince des hirondelles chaque année. Les nominés sont ceux qui, au printemps, repèrent la première hirondelle de l’année. Fin mars, début avril, ils sont ainsi plusieurs à guetter dans le ciel, le retour des hirondelles ».
À lire aussi
Nature : savez-vous pourquoi le ver luisant projette une lumière verte les nuits d’été ? Un inventaire participatif Dans le cadre des actions menées dès cette année, un inventaire participatif des hirondelles et martinets de la commune va être effectué dans la 2e quinzaine de juillet afin d’avoir une meilleure connaissance de leur population. « Les habitants sont invités à aider la commune et la LPO Bretagne à cette mission », invite Viviane Troadec.
Des flyers sont disponibles en mairie pour reconnaître les trois principales espèces visées par ce programme : hirondelle de fenêtre, hirondelle rustique et martinet noir.
Suivez toute l’actualité de vos villes et médias favoris en vous inscrivant à Mon Actu .
#Environnement

author: La Opinión de Murcia
title: Dos amigos de Murcia, obligados a volver de su viaje a Italia tras quedarse sin dinero la primera noche, advierten: "No caigan" - La Opinión de Murcia
text: Dos amigos de Murcia, obligados a volver de su viaje a Italia tras quedarse sin dinero la primera noche, advierten: "No caigan" La de los dos murcianos ha sido una de las historias con moraleja más impactantes del verano Con el verano llegando a su fin y muchos viajeros volviendo a sus casas, es hora de hacer balance de las vacaciones para muchos. Algunas personas traen anécdotas inolvidables, fotos impresionantes y experiencias enriquecedoras, pero también hay quienes regresan con historias de aprendizaje que se convierten en advertencias para otros. Una de las publicaciones más virales y más curiosas de esta temporada ha sido la de dos amigos murcianos que vieron cómo sus vacaciones en Italia se esfumaban en cuestión de horas y que se hicieron virales en redes sociales después de que una cuenta se hiciera eco de su historia. Urgente vuelta de su viaje a Italia tras perder todo su dinero Según contaron ellos mismos, Adrián y Manolo, dos jóvenes de Murcia, pasaron meses ahorrando para hacer un viaje que era su sueño a Roma. Después de pasar semanas trabajando duro y conseguir reunir 950 euros cada uno con la esperanza de disfrutar de dos semanas de descanso y turismo en la capital italiana, tuvieron que volverse casi nada más llegar. La historia de estos amigos se hizo viral cuando uno de ellos la compartió en una reseña en Google Maps, donde explicaba cómo un encuentro casual con un hombre bien vestido en la capital italiana había cambiado el rumbo de sus vacaciones. Según contaban, aquella noche decidieron "salir de tranquis" para celebrar que acababan de empezar su viaje y fueron convencidos por este desconocido para entrar en un club. El hombre les prometió que dentro encontrarían "chicas muy guapas", y los jóvenes, confiados y animados, decidieron entrar. Una vez dentro del club, la situación se complicó y seducidos por las camareras, quienes los hicieron sentir que habían ligado, los murcianos comenzaron a consumir más y más bebidas. La noche, que parecía una velada divertida, terminó costándoles todo su dinero y cuando se despertaron al día siguiente descubrieron con horror que sus cuentas bancarias estaban vacías porque les habían cobrado cuatro botellas de Moet y seis horas de servicios privados, dejándolos sin un solo céntimo. Desesperados y sin fondos para continuar con su viaje, Adrián y Manolo se vieron obligados a pedirle dinero a la madre de Manolo para poder volver a España terminando así su aventura en Italia, que debía durar dos semanas y terminó abruptamente después de solo dos días. author: Sandy Fitzgerald
title: HHS Secretary Kennedy Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs
text:
By Sandy Fitzgerald | Thursday, 27 March 2025 10:33 AM EDT
Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is expected to announce drastic changes to his department Thursday, including cutting 10,000 full-time employees and closing regional offices, according to documents outlining the plans.
The cuts in the workforce are in addition to the roughly 10,000 employees who chose to leave their jobs through voluntary separation plans after President Donald Trump took office, reports The Wall Street Journal, which viewed the documents.
The cuts include:
The plan would shrink the department to about 62,000 by removing one-quarter of its workforce and eliminating five of the HHS's 10 regional offices, according to the documents, which add that essential health services will not be affected.
The employees being let go are spread among departments nationwide that are tasked with the approvals of new drugs, providing insurance for the nation's poorest people, responding to disease outbreaks, and more.
The CDC, meanwhile, will return to its "core mission" of preparing for and responding to epidemics, according to the documents. Its cuts are not to come from the divisions that focus on infectious diseases, an HHS official said.
The reorganization further calls to centralize HHS communications, information technology, procurement, human resources, and policy planning efforts that are now distributed through the department's divisions and some branches.
The secretary is also planning to create a new subdivision, the Administration for a Healthy America, combining HHS offices addressing toxic substances, occupational safety, addiction, and more into one central office. It will focus on programs addressing chronic disease prevention and health resources for low-income Americans.
Kennedy, a frequent critic of the HHS in the past, ran for president last year on a platform to address chronic disease in America. After he endorsed Trump in August, the two said they were going to "make America healthy again."
The Trump administration, through efforts by the Department of Government Efficiency, led by Elon Musk, has cut thousands of federal government employees. Several lawsuits have been filed to challenge the dismissals.
The cuts are not to affect the FDA's inspectors or food reviewers, and several FDA probationary workers who had been cut last month were rehired a week later.
The plan also calls for several offices to shift.
The Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response, which oversees the Strategic National Stockpile and pandemic preparedness planning, is to be moved under the CDC, rather than operating as it does now as a separate division.
Kennedy's Administration for a Healthy America is to include the Health Resources and Services Administration, the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health, the Substance Abuse and the Mental Health Services Administration, along two divisions under the CDC, the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.
Other offices relating to adjudicating or investigating disputes related to Medicare or other areas of HHS are to move to be under a new Assistant Secretary of Enforcement.
In addition, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will merge with the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation to form a new Office of Strategy, and programs for older adults currently under the Administration for Community Living will move to other divisions of HHS, including CMS.
Sandy Fitzgerald has more than three decades in journalism and serves as a general assignment writer for Newsmax covering news, media, and politics.
